awd_titl_txt: Understanding Hate Crime Victimization and Reporting
awd_abstract_narration:
The Hate Crime Statistics Act of 1990 requires the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) to publicly report hate crime statistics. However, hate crimes are often under-identified, and variation in reporting hate crimes across communities is largely unexplored. This project will investigate deviation in the nature and extent of hate crime victimization and the reporting of hate crimes across local communities. 

This research will examine data on hate crime victimization and reporting from the restricted version of the 2005-2015 National Crime Victimization Survey provided by the Federal Statistical Research Data Center, as well as state and local data from multiple sources, including the Decennial Census, American Community Survey, and Law Enforcement Management and Administrative Statistics survey, among other data sources. The project will investigate the effects of contextual and other characteristics on hate crime victimization and reporting. Findings from this project will aid scholars, policy makers, and the public on issues related to hate crimes, including localized variation in hate crime and reporting, data-collection strategies, better identification of strategies to attend to the needs of victims, and assessment of programs that pertain to hate crime victimization and reporting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Hate Crime Statistics Act of 1990 requires the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) to publicly report hate crime statistics. However, hate crimes are often under-identified, and variation in reporting hate crimes across communities is largely unexplored. This project investigated deviation in the nature and extent of hate crime victimization and the reporting of hate crimes across local communities. This research examined data on hate crime victimization and reporting from the restricted version of the 2005-2015 National Crime Victimization Survey provided by the Federal Statistical Research Data Center, as well as state and local data from multiple sources, including the Decennial Census, American Community Survey, among other data sources. The project investigated the effects of contextual and other characteristics on hate crime victimization and reporting. Our findings clearly demonstrate the nuanced relationships between context and hate crime victimization and reporting. For example, our results revealed a nonlinear, bell-shaped effect of the percent Black on the risk of racial hate crime victimization. We also observed that percent Hispanic had a nonlinear, bell-shaped effect on hate crime victimization based on ethnicity or nationality. These effects are also region-specific. Additionally, we found that the risk of hate crime victimization is higher in places with a higher percentage of Whites experiencing an influx of the Black population, and with higher levels of residential instability and ethnic heterogeneity. We also reported some interesting contextual effects on hate crime motivated by sexual orientation, disability, perceived religion. Our results indicated that the effects of contextual variables diverge by race, ethnicity, and gender of the victim. Finally, our results showed that the relationship between the race of the offender and the race of the victim matters when predicting the risk of hate crime victimization, and that historical and socio-economic context can influence this relationship. Findings from this project aid scholars, policy makers, and the public on issues related to hate crimes, including localized variation in hate crime and reporting, data-collection strategies, better identification of strategies to attend to the needs of victims, and assessment of programs that pertain to hate crime victimization and reporting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
